transcripts.text: Hi everyone.  Okay, so I was sent a request on Patreon.  Thank you very much for your pledge, by the way.  A request for one of Jordan's videos that I originally skipped.  I didn't think it seemed like that much fun, but hey, if that's what you want, I'll see what I can do.  So let's listen to Jordan talk about tarot because, of course, if it's stupid, he's into it.
As you may be aware, we've been developing a very special spirit science tarot deck called Patch Tarot.
Okay, remember that.  This is special tarot.  Special tarot.  Think about that.
Our understanding is that tarot is a pictographic card-based diagram of everything in creation.  The visible and the invisible, the known and the unknown.

Wow, we're off to a great start.  You're already spouting nonsense.  First of all, a deck of cards is not a diagram.  If you arrange them on a table, for example, they would perhaps constitute a diagram.  I guess you could say that, but if you rearrange them, it would be a different diagram.  What's the point?
We consider it to be an ancient science rooted in Hermeticism, Kabbalah, and other ancient symbology.
Science.  I'll remember you said that.

Tarot actually originated in the world sometime in the 14th century Europe, and herein it was a simple card game fashioned in a make-your-own-adventure style of game.  It was not thought of or used as any form of science or thought sequence other than a way for aristocrats to enjoy themselves in their spare time.  And yet, sometime after its initial adoption in Europe, A few clever esoteric scholars recognized certain patterns within the tarot that allowed it to be developed in relationship to the established esoteric understandings at that time.

Not quite the first to assign divinatory meanings to the cards was Jean-Baptiste Aliette in 1783.  There's no mention of tarot being used for divination or any other occult purposes.  prior to 1781 when Court de Gebelin, which I'm Probably mispronouncing.  Pulled some connection between tarot and ancient Egyptian mythology straight out of his ass without any evidence whatsoever.
